fullDescription:
The Sage of Yoga - Author of the Yoga Sutras

Patanjali stands as the foundational systematizer of yoga philosophy. His Yoga Sutras, comprising 196 concise aphorisms, codified the ancient practices of yoga into a coherent philosophical system that continues to guide millions of practitioners worldwide. Whether historical figure, mythological sage, or multiple authors writing under one name, Patanjali's influence on spiritual practice is immeasurable.

Historical Mystery and Mythological Identity

The identity of Patanjali remains shrouded in scholarly debate. Traditional dating places him around the 2nd century BCE, though some scholars argue for dates ranging from the 4th century BCE to the 5th century CE. The name 'Patanjali' may refer to one or more individuals, as works on yoga, grammar, and medicine are all attributed to this sage.

Mythological accounts present Patanjali as an incarnation of Ananta Shesha, the thousand-headed serpent upon whom Lord Vishnu reclines. According to legend, Patanjali fell (pat) from heaven into the praying (anjali) hands of a woman named Gonika, hence his name. Traditional iconography depicts him with a human upper body and a serpent's coiled tail, often with a multi-headed cobra hood, symbolizing his connection to the primordial serpent of cosmic support.

This serpent imagery carries profound symbolism: Shesha represents the residue (shesha) that remains when the universe dissolves, the eternal consciousness underlying all existence. As Shesha's avatar, Patanjali embodies the transmission of eternal wisdom into temporal form.

The Yoga Sutras: Structure and Philosophy

The Yoga Sutras consist of 196 sutras (aphorisms) divided into four chapters (padas):

1. Samadhi Pada (51 sutras) - On Contemplation
Defines yoga and describes the nature of the mind, its fluctuations (vrittis), and the states of consciousness leading to samadhi (absorption). The famous opening sutra declares: 'Yogas chitta vritti nirodhah' - Yoga is the cessation of the fluctuations of the mind.

2. Sadhana Pada (55 sutras) - On Practice
Describes the practical means for achieving yoga, including the afflictions (kleshas) that bind consciousness and the eight limbs (ashtanga) of yoga practice.

3. Vibhuti Pada (56 sutras) - On Accomplishments
Explains the inner practices of dharana (concentration), dhyana (meditation), and samadhi, along with the supernatural powers (siddhis) that arise from advanced practice.

4. Kaivalya Pada (34 sutras) - On Liberation
Describes the nature of liberation (kaivalya), the distinction between pure consciousness (purusha) and matter (prakriti), and the final release from the cycle of rebirth.

The Eight Limbs of Yoga (Ashtanga)

Patanjali's most influential contribution is the systematic presentation of the eight limbs of yoga:

1. Yama - Ethical restraints: non-violence (ahimsa), truthfulness (satya), non-stealing (asteya), continence (brahmacharya), non-possessiveness (aparigraha)

2. Niyama - Personal observances: purity (saucha), contentment (santosha), austerity (tapas), self-study (svadhyaya), surrender to the divine (ishvara pranidhana)

3. Asana - Posture: steady and comfortable seated position for meditation

4. Pranayama - Breath control: regulation of inhalation, exhalation, and retention

5. Pratyahara - Sense withdrawal: turning awareness inward from external objects

6. Dharana - Concentration: fixing the mind on a single point

7. Dhyana - Meditation: unbroken flow of awareness toward the object of concentration

8. Samadhi - Absorption: complete merger with the object of meditation, loss of separate self-awareness

Philosophical Framework

Patanjali's yoga belongs to the Samkhya-Yoga darshana (viewpoint), one of the six orthodox schools of Hindu philosophy. Key concepts include:

- Purusha: Pure consciousness, the witness, unchanging and eternal
- Prakriti: Primordial nature/matter, the source of all mental and physical phenomena
- Chitta: The mind-stuff, including intellect (buddhi), ego (ahamkara), and mental processes (manas)
- Vrittis: Mental fluctuations that obscure the true nature of purusha
- Kleshas: Afflictions that perpetuate suffering - ignorance (avidya), egoism (asmita), attachment (raga), aversion (dvesha), and clinging to life (abhinivesha)
- Samskara: Mental impressions that create habitual patterns
- Kaivalya: Liberation through the discrimination of purusha from prakriti

Other Works Attributed to Patanjali

Traditional accounts attribute two other major works to Patanjali:

1. Mahabhashya ('Great Commentary') - An extensive commentary on Panini's Ashtadhyayi, the foundational text of Sanskrit grammar. This work is considered one of the most important texts in Sanskrit linguistics.

2. A treatise on Ayurveda (traditional medicine) - Less certainly attributed, this would make Patanjali a master of body (medicine), speech (grammar), and mind (yoga).

Whether these represent one polymath or several scholars sharing a name remains debated. The traditional view unifying all three reinforces Patanjali's image as a complete sage addressing human development on all levels.

Legacy and Influence

Patanjali's Yoga Sutras became the foundational text for the yoga darshana. Major commentaries include:

- Yoga Bhashya by Vyasa (c. 5th century CE)
- Tattva Vaisharadi by Vachaspati Mishra (9th century)
- Raja Martanda by King Bhoja (11th century)
- Yoga Varttika by Vijnanabhikshu (16th century)

In the modern era, Patanjali's influence has been profound:

- Swami Vivekananda's 'Raja Yoga' (1896) brought the Yoga Sutras to Western audiences
- B.K.S. Iyengar, Pattabhi Jois, and other modern yoga masters base their teachings on Patanjali's system
- The global yoga movement, with hundreds of millions of practitioners, traces its philosophical foundations to the Sutras
- Academic study of consciousness and meditation increasingly engages with Patanjali's insights

Patanjali's genius lies in his systematic condensation of vast yogic knowledge into memorable, precise aphorisms. His work bridges the gap between philosophical insight and practical application, offering both a map of consciousness and a method for its transformation.
